pull_request.title: Eliminate openssl test code dependency
pull_request.body:
Fixes #137 

Jinja2 enablement as followup to https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/pull/151#issuecomment-1530795347 fixing [expected CI failure](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/actions/runs/4858204340/jobs/8659394008).

Adding:
- Fixup to `openssl` build script (to use absolute install paths)
- Making QSC encoder optional (as per https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/issues/152#issuecomment-1531452302)
- Removing dependency on `openssl` test cert by importing & using it locally

review.body: Just a comment regarding the placement of this PR: The code you are suggesting to change is automatically imported to `liboqs` from [PQClean](https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean), so it would be more suitable to propose the code changes there instead of in this project.

pull_request.title: src/kem/kyber/.../*.S, src/sig/dilithium/.../*.S: Return using `ret'
pull_request.body:
Partly, `lr' isn't a register alias under older versions of GNU `as'. But, mostly, `br' doesn't mean the same thing to the branch predictor, so it will cause unnecessary misprediction stalls.

<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

review.body: Thanks for the contribution. Is (possibly not correctly) supporting compilers this old really an issue, though? General question: Does `liboqs` really want to support compilers this old or rather add documentation and compiler version checks (for a certain minimum version) to minimize our efforts on outdated software? We also check for minimum `cmake` version, for example... Thoughts @dstebila @xvzcf @christianpaquin ?

pull_request.title: src/common/pqclean_shims/compat.h: Fix polyfill version check sense

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

review.body:
Thanks for the contribution. Is (possibly not correctly) supporting compilers this old really an issue, though? General question: Does `liboqs` really want to support compilers this old or rather add documentation and compiler version checks (for a certain minimum version) to minimize our efforts on outdated software? We also check for minimum `cmake` version, for example... Thoughts @dstebila @xvzcf @christianpaquin ?

Add: One of the [CI failures in the Sphincs+ update](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/actions/runs/4462022915/jobs/7836295816?pr=1420) are also related to a `gcc > 7.1` version check (failing: It seems McElice code _will not_ compile for gcc<7.1).
